objdescid.compdate: c. 1780-85The date is based on stylistic considerations.

objinfo.medium: pencilThe inscriptions are in pencil. These are not by Blake; see the Editors' Notes.

provenance.name: National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C.
provenance.note: Early history unknown; Alexander Macmillan by 1876; acquired at an unidentified sale by the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach, 22 Dec. 1938; Lessing J. Rosenwald; given by Rosenwald to the National Gallery of Art, Washington, in 1943.

repository.addressline: Constitution Avenue NW, between 3rd and 9th Streets
Mailing Address: 2000B South Club Drive, Landover, Maryland 20785

desc.objtitle: Sketch of Two or Three Figures, object 1 (Butlin 148 verso)

objnote.p: There are two pencil inscriptions not by Blake: "26" right of center just below the top margin and "Single" right of the figures in the drawing.

illustration.illusobjdesc: At least two elongated figures stand on the left side of this drawing. Both are likely gowned and may wear hats. Both may be fleeing to the left. The figure at far left appears to stand facing forward with its back and at least one knee bent forward. This figure may raise a bent arm, or both arms, to touch the side of its face or cover one or both ears. At right, the second figure faces forward with head turned slightly to the right and both arms raised and bent upward to cover its apparently oversized ears. The figure appears to stand on its left foot and extend its right backward and to the right, foot pointed downward on tiptoe. A serpentine line extends rightward from this figure's waist across the drawing. There are various other shapes and lines that may be indications of a landscape.

component.illusobjdesc: At least two figures stand on the left side of this drawing. Both are likely gowned and may wear hats. Both may be fleeing to the left. The figure at far left appears to stand facing forward with its back and at least one knee bent forward. the posture is somewhat twisted. This figure may raise a bent arm, or both arms, to touch the side of its face or cover one or both ears.

At least two figures stand on the left side of this drawing. Both are likely gowned and may wear hats. Both may be fleeing to the left. At right, the second figure faces forward with head turned slightly to the right and both arms raised and bent upward to cover its apparently oversized ears. The figure appears to stand on its left foot and extend its right backward and to the right, foot pointed downward on tiptoe. The figure may be walking or running.
A serpentine line extends rightward from the waist of the figure at right across the drawing. There are various other shapes and lines that may be indications of a landscape.
